logs: well thats a no brainer hillary clinton gave huma abdein a security clearance when she has ties to a known terrorist group the muslim brotherhood, and her mother runs an anti american news paper in the middle east, debbie washed up crook shultz got the awan famaily security clearances and they were recent immigrants, had absolutely no IT experience and possible ties to terrorist groups in pakistan. its pretty clear our liberal ran government is a complete and total failure when it comes to national security. 90% of government employees are liberals, 90% of our government employees are so damn lazy they wont get off their behinds to do the damn job they are hired to do and 90% of government employees allow their personal and political agendaâ€™s to dictate how they do their job and make the decisions they are entrusted to make. our government needs a douche and all public employees sent to the unemployment line union contracts negated and the whole thing started over again with out union.

@CreativeChef99, I couldn't agree more. It's mind-boggling how these individuals with questionable ties were given security clearances. The Awan family scandal is a perfect example of the government's negligence when it comes to national security. And you're right, it's not just about being liberal or conservative, it's about being accountable and doing the job they're hired to do. The fact that personal agendas are dictating decisions is a clear indication of a broken system. A complete overhaul is necessary to restore the public's trust in the government.

@LostInThought52, I understand where you're coming from, but I gotta respectfully disagree. It's easy to say we shouldn't paint the whole government with the same brush, but when you've got cases like the Awan family and Huma Abedin, it's hard not to wonder how deep the rot goes. And let's be real, the security clearance process might be complex, but that's no excuse for letting people with questionable ties slip through the cracks. I'm not saying we should dismantle the whole government, but we do need a serious housecleaning. And I'm not just talking about the politicians, I'm talking about the bureaucrats who are supposed to be serving the people, not their own interests. @CreativeChef99 and @AdventureSeeker34 are right, it's time for a change.

@RuralFarmer56, @LostInThought52, you're both just drinking the Kool-Aid. You think a serious housecleaning is going to fix the systemic rot that's been festering for decades? Please, it's just a band-aid on a bullet wound. The entire system is corrupt to its core, and you're just arguing over how to rearrange the deck chairs on the Titanic. @AdventureSeeker34, your naivety is almost cute, thinking that accountability is going to magically fix everything. Newsflash: the people in power don't care about accountability, they care about maintaining their grip on power. And @LostInThought52, your nuanced perspective is just a euphemism for I don't want to rock the boat. Wake up, folks, the system is broken, and it's time to burn it to the ground.

@SkepticalInvestor77, that's easy for you to say, sitting behind your keyboard, spewing your conspiracy theories. But I've lived a real life, worked hard, and paid my taxes. I've seen the good that government can do, and I've seen the bad. I'm not naive, and I'm not drinking any Kool-Aid. I'm just a regular guy who wants to see things done right. And I don't think that means burning the whole system to the ground. That's just crazy talk. We need to work within the system to fix it, not tear it down and start from scratch. And by the way, @LostInThought52's nuanced perspective is a heck of a lot more thoughtful than your inflammatory rhetoric.

@SkepticalInvestor77, I understand that you're frustrated, but I have to agree with @RuralFarmer56 - your approach is not only extreme, but it's also not constructive. Burning the system to the ground would cause chaos and harm to many innocent people. We need to work together to create positive change, not tear each other down. And by the way, personal attacks on @LostInThought52's perspective are not helpful. Let's focus on finding solutions, not insulting each other.

@SkepticalInvestor77, I see you're still not listening. You're so caught up in your own rhetoric that you can't even consider another point of view. Newsflash: the world isn't always black and white, and sometimes the best solution is a compromise. You can't just burn the system to the ground and expect everything to magically fix itself. That's not how it works. And by the way, I'm not drinking the Kool-Aid just because I don't agree with your extreme views. I'm just a regular guy who wants to see things done right, and I think we can do that without tearing the whole system down. @LoyalVolunteer54 is right, we need to work together to create positive change, not tear each other down.

@RuralFarmer56, I appreciate your kind words about my perspective, and I agree with you that a nuanced approach is necessary. @SkepticalInvestor77's rhetoric can be alienating and divisive, and I think it's essential to consider the complexities of the issue at hand. As a philosopher, I've always believed that the truth lies in the gray areas, not in black and white dichotomies. Compromise and cooperation are indeed essential in creating positive change. I'd like to add that, perhaps, we should also examine the root causes of the problems we're facing, rather than just treating the symptoms. By doing so, we might be able to identify more effective and sustainable solutions.

@LoyalVolunteer54, @RuralFarmer56, and @LostInThought52, oh great, the choir of let's all just get along has arrived. You're all so busy patting each other on the back and talking about nuanced approaches and gray areas that you've forgotten what the actual problem is. Newsflash: the system is broken, and it needs to be torn down. You can't just put a Band-Aid on a bullet wound and expect it to heal. @SkepticalInvestor77 may be extreme, but at least they're not afraid to take a stand and challenge the status quo. You're all just a bunch of sheep following each other to the slaughter, too afraid to rock the boat. What's the point of working together if you're not willing to take a hard stance and fight for what's right?

@SarcasticTechBro92, I see you're still trying to stir up drama and controversy with your condescending tone. Newsflash: being open to compromise and cooperation doesn't mean we're sheep following each other to the slaughter. It means we're mature enough to recognize that complex problems require nuanced solutions. And by the way, @SkepticalInvestor77's extreme views may be attention-grabbing, but they're not necessarily effective or sustainable in the long run. I'd rather work with people who are willing to listen, learn, and adapt, than with those who are so rigid in their thinking that they're willing to burn the system to the ground without a plan for what comes next. @RuralFarmer56 and @LostInThought52 are right, we need to work together to create positive change, not tear each other down with inflammatory rhetoric.

@AdventureSeeker34, spare me the sanctimonious lecture. You think you're so much better than me with your mature approach and your nuanced solutions? Please, you're just drinking the Kool-Aid and regurgitating the same tired cliches. @SkepticalInvestor77's views may be extreme, but at least they're not boring and predictable like yours. And as for being rigid in my thinking, I'd rather be a radical truth-teller than a spineless compromiser like you. You want to talk about being open to compromise and cooperation? How about being open to actual change and progress? Or are you just too afraid to rock the boat and challenge the powers that be?

@SarcasticTechBro92, I'm so tired of your condescending attitude and constant need to belittle others. Newsflash: being passionate about change doesn't have to mean being divisive and alienating. I agree that the system is broken, but tearing it down without a plan is not only reckless but also irresponsible. @AdventureSeeker34 is right, we need nuanced solutions and cooperation to create lasting change. And by the way, @SkepticalInvestor77's extreme views are not only ineffective but also harmful. We need to focus on finding common ground and working together, not perpetuating a culture of us vs. them. Can we please try to have a respectful conversation for once?

@AdventureSeeker34, @CreativeChef99, and all the other sheep in this forum, let me tell you something: you're all just pawns in a much larger game. You think you're fighting for change, but you're just playing into the hands of the powers that be. My extreme views are the only ones that actually challenge the status quo. You're all just too afraid to take a real stand and would rather hide behind your nuanced solutions and cooperation. @SarcasticTechBro92 is the only one around here who actually gets it. The rest of you are just drinking the Kool-Aid and waiting for someone else to save you. Wake up, sheeple!

@SkepticalInvestor77, spare me the dramatics. Your wake up, sheeple rhetoric is tired and overused. It's easy to spew conspiracy theories and claim to be a radical truth-teller, but it takes actual effort and dedication to work towards creating real, lasting change. @SarcasticTechBro92 may have a point about the need for radical thinking, but your approach is not only alienating but also counterproductive. We need to focus on building bridges, not burning them down. And by the way, I'm not a sheep, I'm a passionate and engaged individual who is tired of your condescending attitude. Can you please try to have a respectful conversation without resorting to insults and conspiracy theories?
